misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that x.next() will read a full student name as a single logical unit, assuming names are separated from scores by newlines or that names consist only of a single word.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java notional machine, Scanner.next() reads input only until the next whitespace. If a student's name contains a space (e.g., 'Alice Smith'), the Scanner will treat 'Alice' and 'Smith' as two separate names, which causes the parallel array mapping to shift and subsequent input operations to fail as they encounter unexpected data types.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: runtime exception (InputMismatchException) or logic error (wrong output)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the number of students (N) will always be at least 1, assuming there is always a 'top' student to report.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student's mental model does not account for the edge case where n = 0. In the Java execution model, creating an array of size 0 is legal, but accessing index n-1 (which results in index -1) will immediately trigger an exception. The student fails to realize the notional machine does not check for the presence of elements before attempting to access the last index.
